intro: Inversodicraea gabonensis, commonly known as the Gabon sandpaper tree, is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family and is native to Central Africa. It is a deciduous tree that can grow up to 20 meters tall, characterized by its rough, sandpaper-like bark. The leaves are alternate, simple, and often have a waxy coating, while the flowers are small and inconspicuous, typically clustered in cyathia. The plant produces woody capsules as fruit, which contain numerous seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in dry forests and woodlands.
